newsitem.title: USA: Union Texas, Oman in Caspian Kazakh venture.
newsitem.headline: Union Texas, Oman in Caspian Kazakh venture.

text.p: Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc said Wednesday it signed agreements to form a joint venture with Oman to explore for and produce oil and gas in the Kazakh part of the Caspian Sea and onshore Kazakhstan.
The company said it will serve as operator of the new venture and will own a 75 percent interest.
Oman Oil Co Ltd, a state-owned project development company of Oman, will retain a 25 percent interest.
Terms of the agreements were not disclosed.

"This joint venture with Oman Oil Company marks a major milestone in Union Texas' strategy to expand our operations and create a significant new core oil and gas asset," said Union Texas Chairman and CEO John Whitmire.
"Central Asia offers unparalleled opportunities to add world-class production and reserves," Whitmire said in a prepared statement.

Union Texas said the venture will explore two onshore blocks in the Atyrau region of Kazakhstan. The company said the venture has budgeted about $11 million for seismic and other exploration activities during 1997.

The offshore block selections are expected to take place during 1997's third quarter, and The Republic of Kazakhstan is then anticipated to offer the remaining offshore acreage via an international bid tender, Union Texas said.
"This opportunity gives us access to one of the early Kazakstan production-sharing contracts with attractive fiscal terms," the company's chief said.

A U.S. State Department report on the development and shipment of Caspian Sea oil sent to the U.S. Congress in early April 1997 puts the Caspian Sea region's proven recoverable oil reserves at 15.6 billion barrels, with possible reserves at 163 billion barrels.
The report ranks Kazakhstan first in oil reserves among the five countries bordering the Caspian with proven reserves of 10 billion barrels and an additional 85 billion barrels of possible reserves.

Union Texas, which explores for and produces oil and gas overseas primarily in the U.K. North Sea, Indonesia and other strategic areas, said it has opened an office in Almaty, the capital of Kazakhstan.
